<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_connection_values:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN int
MHD_get_connection_values (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                           enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                           MHD_KeyValueIterator iterator,
                           void *iterator_cls)
{
  int ret;
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;

  if (NULL == connection)
    return -1;
  ret = 0;
  for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
    if (0 != (pos->kind & kind))
    {
      ret++;
      if ( (NULL != iterator) &&
           (MHD_NO == iterator (iterator_cls,
                                pos->kind,
                                pos->header,
                                pos->value)) )
        return ret;
    }
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>

suspicious_frags: for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)

if ( (NULL != iterator) &&
           (MHD_NO == iterator (iterator_cls,
                                pos->kind,
                                pos->header,
                                pos->value)) )
        return ret;
explanation: The MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 concerns the three clauses of a for statement and any objects those clauses access that may be modified by the loop body (including called functions). The listed fragments include the full for header and each clause separately, plus the iterator call inside the loop body which may have persistent side effects or modify objects that the clauses read (for example pos or data reachable from pos). These are the relevant code fragments to inspect for compliance. Other fragments in the function (declarations of ret and pos, the NULL check of connection, the ret increment, the if (0 != (pos->kind & kind)) test structure, and the final return ret) do not affect the well-formedness of the for loop under Rule 14.2: they either do not participate in the for statement clauses, do not read objects used by the loop clauses, or are simple local operations and therefore do not need further investigation for this rule.
